commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. It may lead to a second opinion  (4)
2. Old story coming straight from the horse's mouth?  (6)(3)
3. House in Milan  (6)
4. Ball two?  (10)
5. Toy with one's food, perhaps?  (5)(4)


ALSO
TROJAN WAR
ARMANI
AFTERPARTY
HAPPY MEAL
Smooth sailin'
For what it’s worth, a lot of Web browsers make you jump through hoops now to visit a site starting with HTTP… if they’ll even do it at all. The much preferred prefix is https.

Thought I was going to lose my streak today. Spent 7 minutes checking and double checking. Had no idea what an OLEATO was, and wasn't particularly sure of the crossings, but they all seemed reasonable. Was convinced that a soghrum was a type of fish, and uLIUM seemed like a plausible name for a bone. Decided to fidget with that crossing and tried all five vowels. The I got me the Gold Star. 24 days!
what's a JDATE?
A nice story of puzzle collaboration among friends. Deb’s column refers several times to one co-constructor as Mr. Orenstein — seems like it should be Mr. Hartstein.
Fun puzzle except for 65A.

Liked the puzzle today, a good Wednesday, just the right amount of challenge. Well done, Aidan and Oren.  

I’ve been traveling lately and am still catching up on reading the comments from the last few days. What an amazing set of puzzles from last weekend! I seriously thought that my streak would end on Friday, then again on Saturday.  The NW on both of those really kicked my onager (hah, emus!).  

And Sunday was a ton of fun! I felt like a real yegg by the end.  (Flashback to the 70’s)

A few months ago I bemoaned the fact that I wouldn’t be able to attend the ACPT event this year and meet some of the people that I have gotten to know through this forum.  After I finally got up the nerve to actually go, I had to change my plans. But for a good reason. 

My first granddaughter Maya was born to my daughter on March 9!  First girl in the family after four grandsons, much like my daughter was the first girl of her generation.  I had a wonderful time being there with them all and glad that I could be there at her birth.  

Just wanted to share my good news with everyone, and maybe I can bore you all with pictures in Stamford next year!
haha! Great not good. Fun solve.

After I finish, get the gold star, etc., it  always asks if I want to "review" the puzzle, and today I thought, yeah, I DO want to review this better than passable, great not good, hits way more than misses, with fine results, puzzle. I put in CYCLOPS at first, but appreciated CALYPSO as an answer, too, especially since the limbo dance is often done to calypso music, especially in Trinidad. 

And I just hate when I see the word sorghum on a menu. It doesn't sound good, it sounds like something gizzardy, pinkish gray pulp, and I know this is irrational, but I often avoid dishes with sorghum that I'd gladly eat if it were called millet. It's funny, you know, millet being a kind of cereal grain, that it was Millet who painted "The Gleaners." Spooky! I wouldn't sleep alone tonight if I were you.

Liked abut and abet, the interchangeable ATTN and HTTP, the clever cluing of Con Artist, and we all know that oleato is even more disgusting in name than sorghum. Oleato sounds like one of those weird dietary fads that led to soiled undergarments back in the 80s or 90s.  

But most of all I liked seeing "fiscal" on a day in which -- oops, you don't need an earful of that!
Awesome Yoda clue. I head of course looking in the herb/vegetable family so was presently surprised

This puzzle really hit the SWEET spot, somewhere between being doable and TIDY, and having just enough of an ANCHO BITE. And I thought the themers were fabulous, keeping me interested throughout; I couldn't wait to unravel them. In Brazil, Battleship was available in printed pads, making it very portable and easy to tuck into a bag for a road trip. Better yet, many school notebooks offered the game in the first few pages (whoever came up with that idea must have had a PhD in adolescent psychology.) Even as we took notes in class, we would secretly play the game. We were all just that great at multi-tasking! Thank you, Messieurs Deshong and Hartstein, for a solve that was as much fun as playing Battleship! P.S. The musical selection today is Boy George with "The Crying Game" – which this puzzle wasn't (and Battleship was... when the teacher caught us.) https://youtu.be/-EPGhjxm0G0?si=ip6vNt6v87baoYlE
Sage colored Sage.   Clue of the week.  Or year.

I thought I would win at Battleship, but I was knocked down a peg.

(I'll have to go off the grid for a while.)

@Deb Amlen

I think you may have mistyped one of these fabulous constructors' last names in your column.  


GREAT puzzle. I laughed at all the MIXED reviews.

Thanks!
“Sage colored sage” - what a clue! A more than passable Wednesday puzzle.

I loved 51A, and not because I have anything against Oklahoma...ok...but...sheesh, I think I'm about to put my foot in it like I have for several days in a row.

So I'll just say that I like some of the songs from their musical.  And I think the state has a really nice, interesting shape.  

Oh, and it's cooler, I suspect, on the average than Texas.  So that would be good for me.

It was the first state other than Colorado that I was in.  So that's kinda dope.

I just spent too much time trying to think of a pun for a three star review of Tesla. Elon on my mind?!

This happens more and more — I read clues wrong!

Not a fan of puns usually but I liked this puzzle!

A sly and funny puzzle, some TILs tucked in here and there and some challenges to get the reviews with only a little to go on.

Thank you, Aidan and Oren. I'll give these AUTHORS a ***** review..

I love puzzles that teach me things I didn't know before. TIL 1) OLEATO is a drink made with olive oil that I'm afraid to even look up because it sounds so disgusting. Anyone tried it? 2) FISCAL's first meaning is related to taxation or public money. I thought it was just basically a synonym for financial until I looked it up. (It does also mean that, but that's the second definition ) https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fiscal 3) A sea COW is an order of fully herbivorous aquatic mammals, which includes manatees. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sirenia 4) A busser either busses or BUSes a table, depending on where you live. (I looked it up because I'd thought the verb was just buss.) https://www.consumersearch.com/home-garden/understanding-difference-bussing-vs-busing-tables-explained There were also a few proper nouns I didn't know but filled from crosses and didn't bother looking up because I'm tired. Proud of myself for guessing RBI from "Diamond stat." Crossword puzzles are doing the job my dad could never seen to manage: teaching me about sports. Loved seeing LeVar BURTON mentioned!
I tried so hard to make OKLAHOMEH work.
Why would there be a sign on a bench that says "wet?"

I found this much easier than yesterday's puzzle. The theme was nice, the fill quite fun - I managed to deal with the proper nouns on my own, even though at first I thought they may defeat me (for example, I don't know any names from Seinfeld. I've watching the brilliant Curb Your Enthusiasm recently, where those names pop up sometimes, but since I never watched that show, they are just not ingrained in my memory). I'm glad I did not enter FRY for actor Stephen - I still remember the puzzle where Stephen from V like Vendetta turned out to be REA rather than Fry, which I found particularly cruel at the time 🤣.

PS. When I get back from work I'll answer yesterday's comment (ehifhbinonly read just now given the time difference) about travelling to places along Wisła [Vee-swah], aka Vistula.

Oren and Aiden, 

I really enjoyed your puzzle today, especially all the clues related to your theme. The 1-10 million clue was my favorite. Thanks!
Can someone please help me understand why AGRA is a city seen on Instagram? I understand Taj Mahal but don't see the connection beyond that...
For 20D [Talking-tos] I held onto EARbUdS for longer than I should have. Really enjoyable puzzle, thanks guys!

The first time I ever saw an Oklahoma license plate was in the 1980’s, when I passed through on my way to Texas. “Oklahoma is OK!”, it cheerfully declared. Not great or even good. Not the Land of Enchantment or Big Sky Country, as other states tagged themselves. Just OK.

Self-deprecating humor or an unfortunate use of a pun? I don’t know, but sometime in the ‘90’s Oklahoma got tired of the ridicule and changed its slogan to “Native America”. More dignified, perhaps, but I think Oklahoma was a lot more fun when it wanted everyone to know it was enthusiastically, unabashedly… OK!

Loved the theme answers.   "MIXED RESULTS" and GOODNOTGREAT Friday are hilarious.   (and the second one is timely)   I also liked the sage sage, and I liked that the NYT got a slightly embarrassing shout-out in its own pages.
    Thanks Oren and Aiden!

Congratulations on your debut, Oren, and welcome back, Aidan.  This was a perfect early week puzzle. 

Great theme, lots of humor.

Five stars.

Possibly my favourite clues this year, 22D made me choke on my cuppa when I realised what it was. I’m not even a SW fan.

Haven’t tried OLEATO but I put butter and salt in my coffee, so I guess it’s similar. Delicious and silky.

The puns made me smile. Overall a delightful, relatively smooth Wednesday, though that top right corner was chewy. Didn’t know the pepper and held on to BencH for too long. 

Hobbling off to the alpacas now, foot still tender from the not so gentle love tap of a heifer. Bless her.
Wonderful puzzle, very nicely done. Favorite fill in recent memory and the theme was excellent! Five stars

At first my heart sank when I didn't know 1A - but actually it was a pretty good solve. Lovely word related clues. 

No idea about the Tulsa clue, and looked up RBI (not Reserve Bank of India) and what to do you know? (Trans. for US readers: Wadda ya know?) It's baseball! 

Some trivia:  fiscus in Ancient Rome referred to wicker baskets where the Emperor's money was stored, funded by taxation.

The capsule reviews in the theme were well executed and smile-worthy.  Ones getting great marks for CONARTISTS also made me smile.  Very fresh and fun puzzle that kept me fully engaged.  I did not TWIDDLE my thumbs while solving and my enthusiasm did not DWINDLE.
Fun Wednesday puzzle,and I especially enjoyed reading the constructors’ notes, so looking forward to more from Aidan  and Oren.

Quite a challenge for me, but ended up being an enjoyable workout - especially having enough crosses for the theme answers to dawn on me. Really clever theme. Looking forward to more from these guys. 

Oh - and my usual puzzle find today. A Tuesday from May 18, 2010 by Peter A. Collins. Not anything spectacular - just don't recall seeing another theme quite like this. Three theme answers straightforwardly clued: 

HORSERUSTLER
STEELTRUSSES
ROBERTRULES

And then the 'reveal' clue and answer: 

"Unclear outcome ... or what can be found literally in 20-, 29- and 47-Across"
MIXEDRESULTS

I'm done. 

...

What a delight.  Well done and congrats on the debut.  

Picking up on our constructor's comment, I've carefully researched the question and Google's AI has provided the most definitive answer: 

"While there's no definitive public information confirming whether LeBron James solves crossword puzzles, there's no evidence to suggest he does not. The New York Times crossword is a popular puzzle, and it's possible he enjoys them, but it's not something he has publicly discussed. "

A sage reply indeed.   We are all doomed.

So difficult to compliment 
a puzzle with the theme of
mediocre reviews.

My brain isn’t awake enough!

Something will come to me.
And it will happen at the very *moment*
it is no longer relevant.

That’s my superpower.

Fantastic one.
Keep ‘em comin!

One of my favorite Weird Al parodies--recorded at a point in career before he could afford fancy "official videos": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-IUMCyAR6U0 ("a muppet, but he's wrinkled and green.")

My solving experience last night was a perfect example of how one's physical condition affects one's solve.  

I got done in about four minutes slower than my average Wednesday time, and slower than the median time posted on xwstats.com.  I didn't find the puzzle that hard, but I had just come back from Morocco, and it was the second solve at home.  (I solved the Tuesday puzzle Monday night right after a long plane ride, but my body hadn't started to feel the fatigue from the long trip and busy week.)

My wife and I were sitting in front of the TV just before that, and I was trying to stay awake with MIXED RESULTS.  

The puzzle was a perfectly good one, and nothing in particular slowed me down; yet something about my fatigue meant that I ended up with a very slow time for me.

I wonder what my experience would have been had I been my usual not-too-tired self.

This puzzle is nothing to write home about


(but I loved it anyway).

If any newbies out there want to practice on a very well made but extremely easy Patrick Berry puzzle, there's one in the New Yorker today: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2025/04/09 Highly recommended for those just getting started.
Took me a while to get on these guys wavelength, but I enjoyed the challenge.
Tough for a Wednesday.  Took 31% longer than average.  Theme answers were good, but most of them were hard for me to come up with without some crosses.

It was “Hah!” after “Hah!” for me from get-go to got-done.  This puzzle was so playful!  Just a stellar mood booster. 

So much to like – that friendly poke at the Times with its flying machine prediction, the PuzzPairs© of TIDY/NEAT and BITE/EAT, the marvelous LE-ending verb trio TWIDDLE, WIGGLE, and DWINDLE, and the terrific Oklahoma and Good Friday theme answers.

Talk about a meteoric rise – this is not only a NYT debut puzzle for Oren, but it’s the first puzzle he’s ever made!

Talk about the potential for crossword history – this is Aidan’s third NYT puzzle, his first two being a Friday and Thursday – so he can be only the second constructor to hit the cycle (a NYT puzzle for every day of the week) in their first seven puzzles (the first being Andrew Ries).  Go for it, sir!

It’s obvious to me that you two have a great time together making puzzles, and please do it some more – thank you so much for this!
Find this one quite easy personally (except oleato - sounds vile) but a neat theme well executed
A very clever Wednesday. I quite enjoyed this one!

3 star review of the kazoo-and-percussion one man band?

HUMDRUM
Loved this one, a lot of fun. Was it easier than this Tuesday’s for anyone else?

Can someone explain 58 down? (Clue: Gobs)

Aton? A ton? I'm lost.

It appears the 66A clue needs "Former" added at the top (at least for the domestic readership). https://www.nbcnews.com/business/consumer/starbucks-discontinue-oleato-olive-oil-coffee-drinks-us-rcna178031

Well....I wanted WRIGGLE to go with DWINDLE and TWIDDLE, but I ran out of room.  Don't ask me why...I just wanted a two-letter opener there, to complete the set.  

For the Lincoln quote, I considered several options.... FACE, STORY....then I tried an Across and found my first name in there, which was somewhat useful.  The "Sorghum relative" was the most help; (I am guessing most folks haven't seen a field of sorghum--or thought it was corn.)  

Just a fun puzzle; I even enjoyed being stumped for a bit after I whipped NURTURE in there at 11D.
I would like 12D to be clued as a "crop such as cabbage or broccoli" and then see if it stumps SamE, who does not believe it's a word.
Great cluing!
Wow, what a great puzzle! Gem after gem! So much fun to figure out these clever clues!

Sage-colored sage. LOL. Clever, it is.

Enjoyed the puzzle. Just enough bite and chew for a Wednesday.

Every consent request to a JDate begins with "Would it be kosher if I ... ?"




"No. But some like it tref."
Sage colored sage made me chuckle. Great theme too. More puzzles about mediocrity!!
I done did this puzz
I like the jab at NYT. ;)

This puzzle was better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick.

Yes, that's actually a reference to Odysseus' other captor, Cyclops.
Great debut from Aidan and Oren! It seems you were born for crossword greatness— look at all the vowels in your names! :)

Awesome job and debut for the friends! Since there was a theme and no current “political people/agendas” were involved then I’m completely satisfied. I surely had a nostalgia moment when I saw the hint, “Reading Rainbow” because I remember watching that show in school sometimes. Also, I agree with the writer regarding SAGE! Can someone explain to me what PDAS means about it being the predecessor of the smartphone? Thanks again and I hope my fellow NYTers have a Wonderful Wednesday and Namaste!!
A struggle. Not only does OLEATO not seem like a real word, it also doesn’t sound like it would taste very good.
Always happy to solve a Wednesday puzzle. 22 minutes today.

I did enjoy solving your puzzle very much, Aiden and Oren! Clearly you make a great team. It seemed like a perfect Wednesday puzzle—many ways in, some crunch, and the clueing was so very good. Had never heard of an OLEATO and the thought of it makes me gag. I see from some comments that Starbucks gave up on it. 
Hoping to see more of your collaborations and/or solo creations too. Please keep them coming. 😊
I wish I had tried this one without turning on Autocheck. I probably would have had to finish it this morning, but it would sort of reminded me of the good old days. A half-hour of fun anyway.
Nice Wednesday romp. Enjoyed the punning "midcult" theme.

Fun again. But I didn't appreciate the reminders to 30A or 69A my desk.
  Nah, I'll decide it's 40A or 51A.

oh and let's not diss Oklahoma.

I have notified the Spelling Bee editors that they have offended the many computer programmers and mathematicians in the world by not allowing "modulo".  I have asked for an explanation and/or an apology for this outrage, but I am not holding my breath.

Strands. No spoilers, please, until after "view all replies"

Even with the hint, I couldn't get this theme. Kind of a stretch.

Strands #402
“That's quite a (tasty) mouthful”
💡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🟡

GOODNOTGREAT was my first theme entry get (with no crosses!) but I unnecessarily stumped myself by filling in donOtMISS -- obviously a 5, rather than 3 star, review. 

Idk, is REPLY really the opposite of forward? It seems to me more of an alternative, but I'm open to correction I suppose 😂

Nice quotation from Confucius in the mini about a skill needed by a swordsperson. Now would that be kinesthetia or prioperception? I  read a couple of the links on the difference yesterday but didn't really grasp it.

Well TWIDDLE was interesting.

Egads, are Starbuck's references my new nemesis, as if TV shows were not bad enough. No TV for about 50 years and no Starbucks since they became the McDonalds of coffee.

Nice Wednesday puzzle, keep up the good work lads.
I wonder where 'bussing' tables comes from? I've never heard it. I've worked in restaurants and the waiting staff always serve and clear.

A Wednesday workout for me. Took close to 30 minutes, but solved it unaided.

Why would a sign on a park bench say "WET"? I must be missing something. WET PAINT might make some sense, but just WET? 

"Opposite of forward?" for REPLY is also puzzling. I might forward an email message or reply to it, but in what sense are these opposites? Maybe someone has already answered this in the comments.

Solid puzzle ... GOODNOTGREAT.

• "AOL" is not an ISP. AOL is a web portal / interface. ISP is the service that enables a network connection to the internet.

• "Drop Down" could reference either a user interface field on a window/page. Or it could mean to hit the floor, as in a fire. That is, a complete move to the bottom. What it does not mean is to merely sag. That would be "droop down".

• Resorting to answers such as "a ton" is just lazy puzzle making. Either make it a 3 cell answer or find a different word for those 4 cells.

After reading some OLEATO recipes, I see now what it is: yet another way for people who don't really like coffee to change it into something else. 

Every morning I have a cup of Peet's Italian roast pure coffee—no sugar, no cream,no milk—oat (not milk) or otherwise.  I honor my morning cup,  I drink it with respect and gratitude.  

When we can no longer afford to buy coffee because of a brutal import tariff and we are roasting hickory shells, or god knows what, on the backyard hibachi to make some ersatz swill, I may actually resort to Oleate and dump in some oat "milk" and olive oil, but I won't kid myself that it will ever take the place of the majestic Arabica, or any other genuine coffee.
Just chewy enough for a Wednesday with a fun theme. Two Thumbs Up!
Great clues! Especially “sage coloured sage”. Enjoyed this one
I enjoyed this one. Thanks!

Wow such a tough Wednesday for me… NE corner was so hard for me because I thought for sure 13 down was ATTN even though that was the answer at 54 across. I know using the same answer is frowned on but it just happened a few weeks ago. HTTP didn’t even occur to me. The it all fell together. Ugh I feel so foolish now. 

There were other tough clues but it was a clever theme
Absolutely loved today’s puzzle.

The reviews are in: this is a delightfully fun and clever puzzle! 

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

The themers were fresh and fun, as was the fill! ATON of smiles and chuckles throughout! 

Some commenters dislike REPLY, but I thought it was great. I felt got in the best of ways. 

Loved the clue for YODA! I also always enjoy the clues like 54D for AGRA. They don't usually trick me anymore but I still enjoy them. 

And a reference to the fantastic Levar BURTON, to boot!? What's not to like!?

What would the Sage-colored sage say about this puzzle?

"Big ABUTS I like. Lie, I cannot."
"Is what it is, it is."

My usual late puzzle find. This was inspired by it dawning on me that APATIENTPATIENT is 15 letters. Well... that's never been an answer but my search did lead me to a Wednesday puzzle from November 21, 1990 by Martha J. Dewitt. Two theme answers in that one, both of them 15 letters. 20a: "Doctor's longanimous clientele" PATIENTPATIENTS and 55a: "Quality possessed by 20 Across" PATIENTPATIENCE Both of those answers making their one and only appearance in any puzzle. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/21/1990&g=55&d=A ....

A very witty Wednesday! Looked up one answer.
Well really two but I had one letter wrong. 😑 Not a typo so no excuses:)

And a bit of an odd answer history search result today. I went and looked up MLK. And...

...  it's been an answer in 37 puzzles, but... the first time was in 1995. It never appeared in a pre-Shortz puzzle. And... MLKJR was an answer in 3 puzzles. The first time in 2014. 

Just a bit... puzzled by that. 

....

Lovely puzzle. Totally agree that [Sage-colored sage] was delightful! Could [Mint-colored mint] could refer to a dollar...? Or maybe mint refers to coins rather than bills.
I would disagree though that EAST is on the "right" of a compass, or even a map - that kind of artificial constraint is surely the reason behind many a lost novice orienteerer...erer...
Enjoyed the theme: simple, original, and cleverly executed - many thanks Aidan and Oren!

Terrific, clever puzzle, thank you Mr. Hartstein and Mr. Deshong.  For some reason the northeast corner stymied me for over eight minutes.  Mr. Hartstein, I think it's safe to say you've got a good future ahead of you, in physics puzzles or crossword puzzles.  Good luck.

Took a long time on this one, even after looking up sprouse and lemar.  Got yoda right away though.  Ground to a halt on NE corner, until checked the column and saw the tricky clue answer to pens.  Rest fell into place then.  Not sure why I struggled to figure out diamond meant baseball so cut was wrong, or to think of earfuls.  Learned about olive oil coffee from this one so I have been warned.

A puzzle of the year contender for me, apart from the NE. Never watched Riverdale, mot familiar with ANCHO, REPO is a bit of an Americanism and NOURISH was just a fraction too much of a stretch with two letters missing. Nonetheless a lot of fun for the first 10 minutes.
Super fun and clever, with a few stumpers.  Good work, thanks, constructors!
I hit 1500 days on my streak today!! 😀

@Steven M. 

Yeah, I usually don't have too much trouble with Wednesday, but this one had me concerned.  I figured the Jewish singles thing was something in Hebrew, and I would need every one of the crosses.  But I didn't.

OLEATO was and is a mystery.  I'm choosing to not learn anything about it because it sounds faux elegant and I hate olives.  (The oil's not too bad, though.)

I missed the word "model" in 59A, and poisoned myself with "crater" for the longest time.

@Steven M. 

I could only think of sweet things as to sorghum (syrup).

@Francis The Latin genus of the olive tree is Olea. So the name makes complete sense to me, though I've never heard of Starbucks.

Just kidding about Starbucks.
@cfmoore Jewish dating website. I used it before. Met someone I liked on it, but alas, it didn't last

@Steven M. 

A lass, it didn't last?
@Mehitabel same. For someone who uses both of these buttons a lot, I really didn’t see it.

@Mehitabel

That was my favorite clue of all! 
It's not always that I get to feel clever, so figuring it out made me feel so proud.
I'm still smiling about it.

@Mehitabel 

Yeah, not an intuitive answer.  I think I needed at least 3 crosses before the light came on.  In hindsight, I think it is close enough for crosswords.

@sotto voce ,

Thank you so much! I felt very fortunate to be there, helping them some with the baby and more with my four-year-old grandson, her older brother.  Who is absolutely super with her, by the way. He gave her one of her first bottles! So much fun to be there.
@NYC Traveler Congratulations!

@NYC Traveler 

Congrats! That’s a beautiful name.
@john ezra Ha! I was just going to say that Oleato sounds much, much worse than sorghum, but I see that you agree. Hadn't heard of it before and kinda wish I didn't know about it now

@john ezra 

I wouldn't mind an earful.  In fact, I think I'd like two earsful...earfuls...two of them.

@john ezra,

You’re right Oleato sounds too much like *olean* (was that what was in the potato chips?) to be appetizing! 😀

@sotto voce

When I was a kid, we played Battle Ship with plain paper on which we'd draw our own grids because Mom didn't think there was any reason to pay for it. Worked fine for us!
@Beth I remember doing this in elementary school in the library on rainy days.

@Kris -- I'm sorry to say, while I love this clue immensely, it will not go on my Favorite Clues of the Week list, as it has been used before (not verbatim, but too close to ignore).  I very well may credit it as my favorite "previously used" clue of the week, however.

@Lewis 

I saw one clue that had "saga sage" in it, but nothing like today's clue with "sage" used twice.

@Steve L -- OMG you are right!  I misread "saga sage" for "sage sage".  Thank you, @Steve, for pointing this out.  I take back my comment, and apologize to the constructors, and to anyone who thought this clue was used before, due to my comment.

This clue goes back into the running for my list, and it will have to be one heck of a week of clues, for it not to make the top five!
@Kris I know! I loved that clue as well. One of the many things I say anymore is, “the world especially the country needs a serious heavy sage”. Namaste!

@Mike

That must always give you a sinking sensation.          
                       °
                         °
                       °
                        °
                       °

Mike,

Maybe you lost at battleships,
but your puns are never B-10.

@Psychonaut 
Hmm… I would’ve said more of a Nile green, but…

@Beth

And to be clear, because it matters to me, I looked these things up *after* finishing the puzzle.

@Beth "I looked it up because I'd thought the verb was just buss."
No, that would be [Respond to flirtation, say] (which was the direction my mind was taking that clue.)

@Bill  Oh yes, thank you. I learned that in my research too. Need to remember it, as I'm sure that sense of the word has and will be used again in puzzles.

@Andrzej I appreciate how much you teach us about the differences between English and Polish and between Polish and American culture.

@Bill I feel like I've been trying forever to remind people that "busses" are kisses and was afraid that Beth's research confirmed that I had finally lost that battle. Maybe I have. I was unaware of the regional differences in the word for table clearing.
@Lee I really wish this was the answer

@Raccoon- 

The bench was recently painted.

@Raccoon- 

Somebody wet themselves there, duh.

Or it rained!

SRSLY

(Sorry for engaging troll mode for a moment here. Sorry not sorry!)

@Raccoon-

I was thinking maybe sprinklers but wet paint or wet pants also valid.
@Raccoon- after a bench is freshly painted it would not be uncommon for a sign to read “WET” or ״WET PAINT”

@Cowgirl 

Why would a sign on a bench say "wet pants"?

@Elizabeth Connors that makes sense, I guess I have never seen a recently painted bench... was imagining a little park attendant running around with signs to warn people about the benches after a rainstorm. That would've been quite a stretch
@Raccoon- Then it would say "Wet Paint". Are we running out of paper here?

@Xword Junkie 

Yes. Most of the paper got wet and was ruined...

@Raccoon- 

Because it's not a great entry - like 65A.

@Andrzej 

Madre de dios, the errors above! Typing quickly on the phone ends badly.

@Bill 

Yes, I saw it. I'm not an expert on sugar, but I've seen many kinds being sold in Poland - if not at supermarkets, then at specialist tea shops. Refined and unrefined; powdered, crystal, cubed or in lumps; dry and wet - maybe some of it is the American-style brown sugar you mean?

@Mtmetz (from yesterday)

The Wisła (Vistula) was Poland's only highway for centuries, and river trade brought prosperity to the settlements on it. Many of them are among Poland's most interesting places to visit.

Kraków is incredible - IMO it's among the continent's most fascinating cities, with a rich history and countless historical monuments: an amazing castle, Romanesque, Gothic and Baroque churches, townhouses, a medieval university, etc. There are also parks, bars, restaurants. If I were to recommend a single place to visit in Poland it would definitely be Kraków.

Warsaw was an ugly, sad and dangerous city in the 1990s, but it has almost completely transformed into a vibrant, interesting and safe place. It's not more worthy of a visit than Kraków, but I think few visitors wouldn't find something cool in it for themselves.

Toruń and Malbork (the town with the world's largest brick castle) are fascianting, too.

There are some other gems along the river, too. Kazimierz nad Wisłą (150 km from Warsaw) is a charming old town, popular for day trips. Sandomierz and Płock are old regional capitals on the river's high banks - the cathedral at Płock has bits almost a thousand years old.

@Andrzej - Toruń is the queen and king of all towns along the Vistula. The old town is unmatched. The music, history, festivals, spirit. Toruń should be on the bucket list of any traveler in Poland.
Forgo communist modernist soulless Warsaw: hie thee to Toruń posthaste! Walk the streets, bridges, waterfront, enjoy the ancientry. Buy some flowers first thing in the morning and some beers last thing on the riverfront. Toruń can not be beat, especially in summer. Na zdrowie! 🇵🇱

@Jane Wheelaghan 

RBIs, or runs batted in, is a statistic for batters in baseball. It refers to the number of runs scored as a result of a batter’s turn at bat, usually because he got a hit, but not exclusively. (The other reasons are not necessary to go into here,)

As I’m sure you know by now, there are three bases that a runner can be stationed at as a result of a hit or other favorable result for the team at bat. So when a batter comes up, if any of those runners (including the batter himself) scores, the batter is credited with an RBI or RBIs. 

For example, if there is a runner on second base, and the batter gets a hit that allows that runner to score, the batter gets an RBI. If there are runners on first and second, and let’s say the batter hits a triple (that is, he can get to third base on a long hit), all the other runners score, and he gets two RBIs. If there are three runners on base (“bases loaded”) and the batter hits a home run (almost always, the ball clears the outfield fence), he and all three runners score, and the batter has four RBIs, the most possible on one turn at bat. This is called a grand slam. 

On April 23, 1999, Fernando Tatis got to bat twice in a very long inning and hit two grand slams in the same inning, resulting in eight RBIs in the same inning. This is a record that might possibly be tied one day, but unlikely ever to be broken. 

Hope this information isn’t clear as mud to you!

@Jane Wheelaghan "fiscus in Ancient Rome referred to wicker baskets where the Emperor's money was stored, funded by taxation."

It's surprising (or not) how many Latin--and hence, our--terms pertaining to government, finance, or law have their origin in the language of agriculture--reflecting Rome's early history as a podunk farm town.

So "pecunia" ("money"<"pecuniary") derives from "pecus" ("herd")--wealth was measured by how many head of cattle one possessed. And "laetus" ("happy"--I can't think of an English descendant save the name "Letitia") was connected with the word for manure--a happy landowner was one whose fields were well fertilized, and hence productive.

And don't forget "pontifex" (<"pontiff"), which literally means "bridge-builder". And forget that whole notion about "building the bridge between men and the gods"--no, the pontifex was originally the official tasked with keeping the bridges (over the Tiber) in good working order--with our aging infrastructure, something our politicians might well keep in mind today.

@Bill
